# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session

import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import plotly.express as px
from plotly.subplots import make_subplots
import plotly.graph_objects as go

%matplotlib inline
source.806571f4:
di=data[data['In which country do you currently reside?']=='India']
dusa=data[data['In which country do you currently reside?']=='United States of America']
dothers=data[data['In which country do you currently reside?']!='United States of America']
dothers=dothers[dothers['In which country do you currently reside?']!='India']
source.d8edab5f:
plt.figure(figsize=(50,120))
a=sns.countplot(
    data=data,
     y='What is your age (# years)?',hue='What is your gender? - Selected Choice')
plt.ylabel('Age Distribution',fontsize=50)
plt.yticks(size=50)
plt.legend(title="Gender Distribution", fontsize=50, title_fontsize=55)
for p in a.patches:
  val = p.get_width()
  x = p.get_x() + p.get_width() + 10
  y = p.get_y() + p.get_height()/2
  a.annotate(val,(x,y),fontsize=50)
plt.show()
source.f7a603e5:
plt.figure(figsize=(25,25))
ques2='Select the title most similar to your current role (or most recent title if retired): - Selected Choice'
q='What is the highest level of formal education that you have attained or plan to attain within the next 2 years?'
# print(data[ques2])
ax=sns.countplot(y=data[ques2],hue=data[q])
plt.yticks(fontsize=25)
plt.xticks(fontsize=25)
plt.ylabel('Current Profession of Kagglers',fontsize=25)
plt.legend(title='Going to be',loc=4,fontsize=25,title_fontsize=25)
plt.xlabel('Count',fontsize=25)
plt.show()
source.95103b2c:
ques29='For how many years have you been writing code and/or programming?'

values29=[each for each in data[ques29]]
values29=list(set(values29))

print(values29)
isizes=[len(di[di[ques29]==each]) for each in values29]
usizes=[len(dusa[dusa[ques29]==each]) for each in values29]
osizes=[len(dothers[dothers[ques29]==each]) for each in values29]
fig = go.Figure(data=[
    go.Bar(name='USA', y=usizes, x=values29),
    go.Bar(name='India', y=isizes, x=values29),
    go.Bar(name='Othes', y=osizes, x=values29)
])
fig.update_layout(barmode='group',title_text='Years of Programming Experience ',yaxis=dict(title='Number of People'),xaxis=dict(title='Years'))
fig.show()

source.6104ccb1:
plt.figure(figsize=(50,100))
a=sns.countplot(
    data=di,
     x='What is your age (# years)?',hue='What is your gender? - Selected Choice')
plt.xlabel('Age group',fontsize=50)
plt.xticks(size=50)
plt.legend(title="India", fontsize=50, title_fontsize=55 , loc =1)
for p in a.patches:
  val = p.get_height()
  x = p.get_x() + p.get_width()/2
  y = p.get_y() + p.get_height()+10
  a.annotate(val,(x,y),fontsize=50)
plt.show()
source.d1291b96:
l=list(data.columns)
words='What programming languages do you use on a regular basis? (Select all that apply) - Selected Choice'
fil=[s for s in l if words in s]
labels=[each.split()[-1] for each in fil]
# print(fil)
print('Languages: \n',labels)
sizes=[data[e].notnull().sum() for e in fil]

fig1, ax1 = plt.subplots(figsize=(15,20))
patches,txt,autotext=ax1.pie(sizes, labels=labels, autopct='%1.1f%%',
        shadow=True, startangle=90)

plt.setp(autotext, size='large')
ax1.axis('equal')  # Equal aspect ratio ensures that pie is drawn as a circle.
plt.legend(
    loc= 4
)
plt.show()
source.4201a40e:
ques="Which of the following integrated development environments (IDE's) do you use on a regular basis?  (Select all that apply) - Selected Choice"
values=[each for each in l if ques in each]
labels2=[each.split()[-1] for each in values]
labels2[0]='Jupyter'
labels2[2]='Visual Studio Code'
labels2[3]= 'Write'
print(labels)
sizes2=[data[each].notnull().sum() for each in values]
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(15,20))

ax.pie(sizes2, labels=labels2,
        autopct='%1.1f%%', shadow=True)
        
#draw a circle at the center of pie to make it look like a donut
centre_circle = plt.Circle((0,0),radius=0.75 ,color='black', fc='white',linewidth=1.25)
fig = plt.gcf()
fig.gca().add_artist(centre_circle)


# Set aspect ratio to be equal so that pie is drawn as a circle.
plt.axis('equal')
plt.show()
source.342ce4ef:
# Taking python as programming Language
python=data[data['What programming languages do you use on a regular basis? (Select all that apply) - Selected Choice - Python'].notnull()]
ques="Which of the following integrated development environments (IDE's) do you use on a regular basis?  (Select all that apply) - Selected Choice"
values=[each for each in l if ques in each]
plabels=[each.split()[-1] for each in values]
plabels[0]='Jupyter'
plabels[2]='Visual Studio Code'
plabels[3]= 'Write'
psizes=[python[each].notnull().sum() for each in values]
plt.figure(figsize=(30,40))
plt.bar(plabels,psizes)
plt.xticks(fontsize=25)
plt.yticks(fontsize=25)
plt.xlabel("IDE",fontsize=30)
plt.legend(title='Python Programming Language',fontsize=25)
plt.show()
source.ad1dabf9:
ques="Which of the following integrated development environments (IDE's) do you use on a regular basis?  (Select all that apply) - Selected Choice - "
length=len(ques)
values2=[each for each in l if ques in each]
labels2=[each[length:].strip() for each in values2]
print(labels2)

Isizes1=[di[each].notnull().sum() for each in values2]
usasizes1=[dusa[each].notnull().sum() for each in values2]
othersizes1=[dothers[each].notnull().sum() for each in values2]

fig = go.Figure(data=[
    go.Bar(name='USA', y=usasizes1, x=labels2),
    go.Bar(name='India', y=Isizes1, x=labels2),
    go.Bar(name='Others', y=Isizes1, x=labels2),
])
fig.update_layout(barmode='group',title_text='Number of people using Different IDE',yaxis=dict(title='Number of People'),xaxis=dict(title='IDE'))
fig.show()

source.df52b9f6:
plt.figure(figsize=(50,100))
ques1='What programming language would you recommend an aspiring data scientist to learn first? - Selected Choice'
ques2='Select the title most similar to your current role (or most recent title if retired): - Selected Choice'

val=[]
for each in data[ques1]:
    if each not in ['Python','R','SQL']:
        val.append('Others')
    else:
        val.append(each)
        
# print(data[ques2])
ax=sns.countplot(y=data[ques2],hue=val)
for p in ax.patches:
  val = p.get_width()
  x = p.get_x() + p.get_width() + 10
  y = p.get_y() + p.get_height()/2
  a.annotate(val,(x,y),fontsize=50)
plt.yticks(fontsize=50)
plt.xticks(fontsize=50)
plt.ylabel('Current Profession of Kagglers',fontsize=50)
plt.legend(loc=4,fontsize=50)
plt.show()

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
ques4='Which of the following hosted notebook products do you use on a regular basis?  (Select all that apply) - Selected Choice - '
length=len(ques4)

values3=[each for each in l if ques4 in each]
labels3=[each[length:].strip() for each in values3]

print(labels3)
sizes3=[data[each].notnull().sum() for each in values3]
fig = px.bar(y=labels3, x=sizes3,title='Number of people using Different Notebooks',labels={'y':'Hosted-Notebooks','x':'No. of People'})
fig.show()

fig.update_layout(barmode='group',title_text='Tools for managing Machine Learning Experiments ',yaxis=dict(title='Number of People'),
                  xaxis=dict(title='Tools for managing Machine Learning Experiments '))
fig.show()

Some popular platforms where we can deploy our models are Github, Kaggle, Colab, Personal Blogs.

# Popular Machine Learning Frameworks

Observation:

1. Scikit Learn
2. Tensorflow
3. Keras
4. Xgboost
5. Pytorch
source.6c6d51d9:
# Popular Computer Vision methods

Observation:
Image segmentation methods (U-Net, Mask R-CNN, etc)', 'Object detection methods (YOLOv3, RetinaNet, etc) is the most popular Computer Vision Method.
source.65575228: Data Science has great scope in future. These cloud products are paving way for practitioners, providing them high computation power and resources. Hence, products provide great insights of data.
source.627bdefa: Above graph, is a clear explanation about future of AutoML around the world. AutoML is going to be more and more popular, among practitioners. AutoML provide great insight about different machine learning processes and help us to get better results. It has automated the process of Data Augumentation, feature engineering, model selection, hyperparameter tuning, pipeline creation and model architecture searches. Thus, help in the production of good quality models.
source.325af2a9:
# Popular Visualization Libaries

Observation:

Top 4 Popular Visualization Libaries :
 
1. Matplotlib
2. Seaborn
3. Plotly / Plotly Express
4. Ggplot / ggplot2
source.369c7006:
# Now, lets find out about the programming Language preferred by people at Kaggle, on regular basis.

Observation:
The top 3 programming language preffered by people are : 1) Python 2) SQL 3) R
source.5f852ff6: As, we can see from above graph, Microsoft Power Bi, Tableau, Google Data Studio and Sap Analytics Cloud are going to become more and more handy in future. These tools provide excellent analysis and indepth exploration of data.
source.6ff4c4c5:
Now, lets consider 3 commonly used languages i.e Python , SQL , R , in order to get better insight of data.

Observation: Python is the most preferred language for an aspiring data scientist and after Python, R is the second preferred language.
source.cee1d52d:
# Lets look which age group and which gender population are most active on Kaggle in India.

Observation:
In India, People in between age-group 18-21 years are most active on Kaggle. Specially, men belong to this age group are more active on Kaggle.
source.43a6370c:
# Business Intelligence Tools used by Kagglers

PopularBusiness Intelligence Tools are :

* Microsoft Power BI
* Tableau
* Google Data Studio
source.290c8d84: Observation:  In India and USA, the most preferred notebook is Colab Notebooks and the second most preferred notebooks is Kaggle Notebooks. But in USA, most of the people are not using Notebooks.

* MySQL
* PostgresSQL
* Microsoft SQL Server
* MongoDB
* SQLite
* Oracle Database
source.e64be8dc: Databases are important part of any computer software. Exploration of data and storing them, are two important factors that cant be ignored.  Cloud Platforms are the best place to store data. Big Data products has huge scope in future as data is an "ever-growing entity".

source.4c76f401:
## ML Products

ML products of Microsoft ,Google and Amazon are going to get more and more popular in future. The computaional and prediction power provided by these products has opened new doors for Engineers. These tools help in more accurate and precise analysis of results.
source.06c7aac6:
# Popular Platforms for Data science Courses

Free platforms such as Cousera, Udemy, Kaggle ,Datacamp , Scholarships in DS are mostly used by people, to learn Data Science Techniques.
source.28213110:
# Graph giving information about number of people active on Kaggle from different countries.

Observation:
India has highest number of active participants on Kaggle. USA has second highest number of active participants on Kaggle.
source.24e1554e:
# Popular ML Algorithms

Observation:

The order of ML Algorithms :
 
1. Linear or Logistic Regression
2. Decision Trees or Random Forests
3. Convolutional Neural Networks
4. Gradient Boosting Machines (xgboost, lightgbm, etc)
5. Bayesian Approaches,Recurrent Neural Networks,Dense Neural Networks (MLPs, etc)
source.80b2a736:
# Tools for managing Machine Learning Experiments 

TensorBoard is most popular tool for managing machine learning experiments
source.40e02e45:
# Cloud Platform to gain popularity in Future


Google Cloud Platform, AWS and Microsoft Azure are providing great scope for AI/ML in Cloud. Thus, gaining popularity in the field of Data Science, and opening new opportunities for learners as well as practitioners.

Collab Notebooks and Kaggle Notebooks are popular among Kagglers .

According to survey, people mostly prefer Jupyter (JupyterLab, Jupyter Notebooks, etc) in order to perform there task.
